narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: History of medicine and disease in the ancient Western world (Greece, Rome, Egypt, and Mesopotamia)
By taking CLCV 330, I gained more knowledge on the history of western medicine and how it has developed into the system we recognize it as today.

This course teaches students to think critically about the foundations of medicine as a science and as a social institution, considering problems in antiquity and tracing their legacy in modern medicine and society as a whole. As both an HSHM and a CLCV course, it's a great example of interdisciplinary education because it ties STEM concepts and humanities, bridging medicine and disease to their social contexts and implications.

increased knowledge of ancient medicine 
skills: how to read ancient texts 
I learned the most while writing my paper though
learned alot about ancient med and hippocratic treatises

I learned about ancient medical cultures in Ancient Greece, Rome, Egypt, and Mesopotamia area. It was a fun class to read ancient texts and deduce their cultures. The highlight of the class was our final presentation, where we did our own research on ancient medical cultures. This is when I realized that weve gained skills to study ancient materials.

I learned about what medicine was like in ancient times such as Rome, Egypt, Greece, and more. I also learned to evaluate ancient medicine from a more sociological lens than I had originally expected. For example, looking at the role of gender in the case of the wandering womb.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
There was a lot of interesting readings and the subject matter was intriguing. 

Class discussions sometimes got a bit dry and the grading was unreasonably harsh. Often many points were taken off for small mistakes on writing assignments, presentations, or exams (particularly losing points for grammar on a timed in-class essay).

This course was great at encouraging direct engagement with the material and involving Yale's vast resources to further those conversations. That being said, more could have been done to engage with the material we were reading about rather than just reading and discussing, such as hands on practicals.

The biggest strength of this course is how in-depth and immersive it is, especially regarding Hippocratic Medicine. It would benefit from more instruction on the writing assignments, and from more exploration into the social contexts of the time outside of medicine.

strengths: interesting readings for the most part, engaging professor 
weaknesses: long-winded class sessions, most classes I felt like there was not much to talk about, boring readings sometimes,
Very reading heavy, grading was all left to TF who was very unhelpful at times

It was a super fun classProf. Lamont and Chris are amazing teachers, and the materials were interesting. It would have been better as a lecture course, though, since we had little in-class discussion. It was mostly prof. Lamont who talked (analyzed texts).

The course provided a very insightful survey on ancient medicine and was especially adept at highlighting voices of individuals and groups who have been historically marginalized. The discussions could have benefitted from a bit more focus and direction (perhaps with direct questions, or assignments to supplement the readings in advance of class) in order to motivate increased levels of student engagement in the seminar. Overall, though, I got a clear and comprehensive view of the medicinal procedures, advancements, and ideas that characterized the ancient world.

Strengths-the topic of this course was so interesting
Weakness-class discussions were not lively

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: No, despite the interesting subject matter, the grading was much too harsh and the stress that this induced made the class impossible to enjoy.
I would recommend this course to students interested in engaging with the history of western medicine.

I would definitely recommend this course to other students, especially pre-med students and history majors, because it adds nuance to the field of medicine and to the role of the physician that is important for students who intend to go into the field to understand. For humanities majors, the course offers a glimpse into how the humanities and sciences overlap and revolve around each other.

if you want to learn more about ancient medicine, sure 
not very helpful or practical information though
Yes if Prof Lamont has a different TF.
Yes! Its a fun class to couple with other HSHM courses like Cultures of Western Medicine.
I recommend this course to another student because the topic is very interesting.
